Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Multilayer Ceramic Electrolyte Membrane (ML-CEM) for a sodium metal-chloride electrochemical cell
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to confirm the performance of a novel, freestanding, nano-structured, multilayered ceramic electrolyte membrane (ML-CEM) design. The ML-CEM will be produced from an anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) membrane in a vapor phase method. The Na+ conductive ML-CEM has an open-porous á-alumina layer providing the required structural strength, and a dense, non-porous, nano- to micrometer thick sodium â-alumina layer allowing facile sodium ion transport. The low thickness of the sodium â-alumina layer will provide sufficient ion-conductivity for an operation of the sodium-based electrochemical cell at, or even below, room temperature, and will exhibit superior ion-conductivity above 200 °C. Therefore, the ML-CEM based electrochemical cells will exhibit high energy and high power densities and a wide operating temperature range, making sodium batteries to become a viable option in many stationary and vehicle energy storage applications.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that ML-CEM will enable low cost electrochemical cell designs. In a stationary application distributed, modular and scalable ML-CEM based sodium batteries will allow electric utilities to shift the power grid operation from peak-power to system energy. This will lead to an improved utilization of the nation?s power grid assets, allows the integration of fluctuating renewable energy sources, enables micro-grid power architecture to improve the stability and reliability of the electric power distribution, and minimizes the risk of cascading power outages. Furthermore, the proliferation of affordable, zero-emission electric vehicles will be supported by high-energy / high-power ML-CEM based batteries. Their robustness and safety, as well as their high calendar and cycle life are providing a significant improvement over today?s electric vehicle batteries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective for this project is the development and commercialization of a sodium nickel chloride (aka zebra) battery capable of operating at lower temperatures and with higher power than current zebra batteries. The main Phase I goal was to prove the feasibility of such a battery by producing and evaluating ML-CEMs for sodium conductivity. The project was extremely successful and all of the Phase I goals were met or exceeded. The feasibility of our electrolyte technology as an electrolyte was established as a foundation of the follow-up Phase II project. The results clearly show that our technology can be used to make a robust and compact electrolyte with a very large sodium conductivity at a temperature of 100°C – bringing a significant performance advantage over conventional β-alumina tube electrolytes.

The batteries that Na4B is developing will be able to compete not only with current sodium-based batteries but also with lithium ion batteries. Our batteries will be significantly cheaper than current batteries with lower weight and without the safety concerns of lithium ion batteries.

The batteries we are developing will also help enable the alternative energy market by providing a way to store the power generated from renewables until it is needed on the grid.


Last Modified: 07/15/2014
Modified by: Monika S Jansohn
